thread.title: Southeastern’s final three games as tough as they come
thread.title_full: Southeastern’s final three games as tough as they come

title: Southeastern’s final three games as tough as they come
text:
Posted: 6:57 p.m. Thursday, Oct. 15, 2015 Southeastern’s final three games as tough as they come By Greg Billing Staff Writer 
Southeastern High School football coach Greg Bonifay made the comment earlier this season after his team struggled to an 0-3 start. 
And, with the Trojans facing their final three games starting tonight, it’s just as true as it was then. 
“I think the attitude of our kids is we will compete,” Bonifay said. “When you compete, good things will happen. You just never know what’s going to happen.” 
That mindset will serve Southeastern well as it faces one of the toughest final three weeks not just in the Ohio Heritage Conference, but in all of high school football. 
Southeastern (2-5) hosts Greeneview (5-2) tonight and finishes on the road at West Liberty-Salem (5-2) and Mechanicsburg (7-0). All three opponents currently hold playoff spots. 
Greeneview is No. 4 in the Division V, Region 18 computer points. Mechanicsburg is No. 3 and West Liberty-Salem is No. 6 in D-VI, Region 22. 
And should Bonifay’s words ring true — “You just never know what’s going to happen” — then the Trojans could vault up the D-VII, Region 26 standings themselves. Southeastern is No. 15 in the region. The top eight qualify for the postseason. 
What a rush: Kenton Ridge senior Jayden Davis closed the gap on Stebbins senior Mason Dyer for the Central Buckeye Conference rushing title. 
Davis rushed for 262 yards and three touchdowns on 21 carries in last week’s win at Shawnee. He had 266 yards and two TDs on 26 carries the week before in a win against Tecumseh. 
For the season, Davis has 1,081 yards and 11 TDs on 124 attempts (8.7 yards per carry). He averages 154 yards per game. 
Dyer, for comparison, has 1,176 yards on 136 carries (8.6 per carry). 
Davis has had two games with single-digit carries, including a two-carry game against Greenon. He scored on both attempts and finished with 34 yards. 
Kenton Ridge hosts Bellefontaine tonight. 
Do-it-all Davis: Springfield junior Danny Davis continues to be one of the more versatile players in the Greater Western Ohio Conference, leading the league in all-purpose yards. 
Entering tonight’s game at Fairmont, Davis has 593 yards rushing, 528 receiving, 184 on punt returns and 124 on kickoff returns for a total of 1,429. 
Trotwood’s Raveion Hargrove is second with 1,279 yards (most coming from 1,161 yards rushing). 
Davis also has 13 of Springfield’s 20 touchdowns: six rushing, six receiving and one punt return. More News From Our News Partners
